About Kevin Quinteros

  1. Home
  2. About

Kevin Quinteros, Ph.D. Candidate

My research focuses on the highly-coevolved plant-insect interactions of the fig and fig wasp pollination mutualism. Fig trees (genus Ficus), with over 800 species, have evolved elaborate floral fragrance and morphological traits to attract species-specific fig wasp pollinators (family Agaonidae). Mutualistic interactions are especially prevalent drivers of diversification in co-evolving species, such as the fig-fig wasp pollination mutualism, because each species reciprocally imposes strong selective pressures for reproductive success. Given the ecological and evolutionary importance of these interactions, it is important to understand their formation and maintenance at multiple biological scales. The fig/fig wasp system provides an excellent opportunity to understand the mechanisms that drive coevolution. Figs and their pollinating fig wasps (family Agaonidae, superfamily Chalcidoidea) are a textbook example of an obligate mutualism in which each partner is dependent on the other for reproductive success.

The 60 million year history of the system has resulted in an extraordinary level of biodiversity. Although, fig trees are a keystone species in their ecological communities, due to their aseasonal production of large fruit crops, they have poorly understood evolutionary history. My dissertation focuses on the fig-fig wasp pollination mutualism investigating: (1) At the community level, fig wasp pollinator turn-over between fig tree species. (2) At the species level, the role of floral fragrance in maintaining pollinator specificity and, consequently, reproductive isolation underlying high observed levels of fig and fig wasp diversity. (3) At the population level, factors, such as barriers to dispersal and gene flow, that lead to geographic differentiation and potential speciation in fig pollinator.
